text: is a region of Japan. It is on the northeastern side of the island of Honshu. Sanriku combines the area of Aomori, Iwate and parts of Miyagi Prefecture. It was sometimes called . Sanriku has an irregular coastline with 36 small bays. Each bay focuses impact power of ocean waves.Satake, Kenji. (2005). Tsunamis: Case Studies and Recent Developments, p. 99. This was shown by the damage caused by the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami. ==History== In 1869, the provinces of Mutsu and Dewa were divided. Mutsu was split into new five provinces: Rikuōku,Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Rikuōku" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 790. Rikuchū,Nussbaum, "Rikuchū" at p. 790. Rikuzen,Nussbaum, "Rikuzen" at p. 790. IwashiroNussbaum, "Iwashiro" at p. 410. and Iwaki.Nussbaum, "Iwaki" at p. 408. The first three of these collectively known as the "Three Riku", or Sanriku.Nippon-Kichi, "Saw-tooth Sanriku Coastline"; retrieved 2012-1-12. The new provinces were abolished in July 1871; however, the regional name is still in use as the Sanriku Coast from Aomori to the Oshika Peninsula in Miyagi.Japan-i, Sanriku Coastline/Kamaishi Daikannon ; retrieved 2012-1-12. ==Notes== Category:Regions of Japan
